titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV. Thursday—

I was awaked this Morning just at day light by the Meeting-House Bell; which rung for a house that was burning down— It belonged to Captain Jenkins at Bent’s Point a man much esteemed, and for whose loss there is great sympathy— He is himself now absent, and this misfortune leaves his family destitute— Captain Smith and Deacon Spear called here early in the day with a subscription paper—to which the contributions were already liberal— Rode this afternoon with the ladies over Milton Hill— I visit my garden every day; but confine my observations to my young trees— My list in the Summer house-cellar is now Oaks 8. Elms 2. Horse Chesnut 5. Peaches 10. Plums 3. Walnuts 4. Catalpa 1. Willow 1— This last has put out four vigorous shoots upon the stem which I left on cutting it down about the 15th. of June— The first shoot appeared within five days after.— I found this afternoon several small Slug worms on the leaves of my two years old Cherry tree— General Sumner says that the small green louse which crumples the peach leaves is an Aphis— Farrar sent me about two quarts of the black Mazzard Cherry from my tree, fully ripe, with part of which I filled a bottle of New England Rum— Of the rest I propose to plant the Stones— All of which sink in water— The white and black hearts from budded trees almost universally float— I finished this morning the Oration for Lucius Cornelius Balbus, and read two Sections of that de Provinciis consularibus. Balbus was a native of Cadix in Spain, to whom Pompey for important Services rendered had granted the right of Roman Citizenship— There was an express ordinance of the Senate authorising Pompey to grant this right; but after Balbus had enjoyed it several years this accusation was raised against him on the ground that by the Treaty of federation between Rome and Cadix no Citizen of the Latter place could be naturalized as a Roman Citizen— This pretension is refuted by Cicero. Balbus was acquitted, and afterwards by the favour of Caesar, rose to the Consular dignity— His nephew of the same name obtained the honours of a triumph— This oration is curious for containing much upon the subject of naturalization or acquired citizenship— Also upon the federal Law, between the Roman Republic and her Allies. The terms fundus fieri as applied to cities, contain the knot of the cause, and something is wanting to make them perfectly intelligible. Balbus from being a Protegé of Pompey had become a great favourite of Caesar; and Cicero apologizes eloquently for undertaking his defense at all— His remarks upon the duty of sacrificing resentments for the benefit of the Republic are sound and pathetic. Balbus was afterwards a faithful friend to him—
2. IV. Friday.

This was a sultry Summer day, and the effects of Summer heat was to produce mere debility without pain beyond any thing I had ever before experienced— It disabled me from writing totally before dinner, and thereby necessarily postponed my proposed occupations— I took a morning bath and swam from wharf to wharf— In the Evening I rode with the Ladies to Milton Hill and called at Dr Holbrook’s; but he was not at home. Hetty Walker left us, this Evening. I finished reading this morning the Oration de Provinciis Consularibus—to the Senate— There was a Law introduced by the father of the Gracchi—when a tribune; requiring that the Government of certain Provinces should be assigned to Consuls and Praetors; before they entered upon their Offices, but their command to commence after the expiration of their official year at Rome— The Provinces of Macedonia and Syria, had been assigned to the Ex-Consuls Gabinius and Piso, by a Law of Clodius, and as a part of his outrageous proceedings against Cicero— And the two Provinces of Gaul, citerior and ulterior had
by a special act obtained by the Tribune Vatinius, but considered by Cicero, and the Senatorial party as illegal, had been assigned to Caesar for five years—nearly one year and a half of which were yet unexpired— The Consuls now put in question how these four Provinces were to be disposed of— Gabinius and Piso, had made themselves so odious in their Provinces, that the general opinion seems to have been that they should be recalled—but Caesar was pursuing a career of splendid victories in Gaul, and was rapidly reducing both its parts into Roman Provinces— To this end, he and his friends wished his command there to be continued for a second term of five years—which measure was vehemently opposed by his enemies and enviers, and generally by the Senatorial party, to which Caesar had always been obnoxious— At this time the Senators whose opinions had been called for, before Cicero, had all advised, that Caesar’s command should not be protracted at least in one of the two Provinces—except Publius Servilius who had opined that his whole command should be continued— In this Cicero concurred, and his Oration is an ingenuous and powerful argument in support of that opinions— He urges the recall of Gabinius and Piso, upon public considerations and disclaiming the influence of all personal resentment against them. But he lashes them without mercy— He does not deny that he had been at enmity with Caesar, and that he had been ardently opposed to the Vatinian Law—but he alledges the splendid Services of Caesar, and the duty of sacrificing individual enmities to the cause of the Republic. He gives a very candid account of his relations with Caesar; and of his differences with him; and concludes that it is impossible for him not to be the friend of one who is the benefactor of his Country— I also read a number of the Letters of Voltaire to Madame du Deffand, and part of his Tragedy of Irene.
3. V. Saturday.

Bath, and swam from wharf to wharf, with greater annoyance of gad-flies than ever. The Sea-bath itself is losing its charm— The exercise becomes fatiguing, and in fancy or in reality it is no longer so conducive to my health as heretofore. We concluded this morning to dismiss the black man, William Taylor, who came with us from Washington— I paid him his wages in full: two Months to the 18th. and sent John Kirke with him to set him down at Boston— It is scarcely possible to keep within any rule of order a family consisting partly of white and partly of coloured Servants. This fellow made a disturbance in the house at Washington, one night before we came away: and has done the same thing here— He denied the fact, and intreated me to keep him upon trial with a promise that I should never hear a complaint of him again— I persevered in discharging him. John Kirke did not return from Boston this day— My Son Charles and his wife came, before dinner, having passed this week at Medford— We resumed after dinner the making out of a Catalogue of my books, till I was fagged by the sultriness of the weather. I have had a piece of ground broken up in my nursery at the right hand of the gate, where I this evening planted a row of 24 mazzard whole cherries from my tree; and two rows of Stones stripped from the same cherries— Some of them I suppose will come up next Spring, and I wish to make the comparative experiment, between planting the whole cherry and the stone— I have fifteen Apple-trees up from the seeds which I carelessly put into the ground last Summer, but as they came up in clusters ten of them, are transplanted, and they live, but do not grow— The English Oaks put forth vigorous shoots, shrub like, without an ascending stalk.
4. V:30. Sunday.

John Kirke returned this morning from Boston, with a white boy named John Phillips, who is to take the place in the family of William the reformed— Heard Mr Whitney this morning from Psalm 48.9. “We have thought of thy loving kindness, O God, in the midst of thy Temple.[”] an occasional Sermon upon the day— The anniversary of Independence falling this year on the Sunday— The afternoon discourse was from Acts 10.34. “God is no respecter of Persons”— The doctrine which Mr Whitney appeared chiefly anxious to enforce was that of future retribution in punishment for evil life— I supposed he had reference to the creed of the Universalists, who are increasing in numbers and burning with the zeal of seeking proselytes— Their chief Apostle in Boston is a Mr Ballou, who holds that there is no future State of Punishment— This is the tenet of one branch of the Universalists— The other admits a temporary purgatory— The unqualified Universalists have sent a teacher here, who has delivered several Lectures; and assembled numerous auditories. Mr Whitney apprehends that they will collect a church here, and draw off some of his parishioners— He quoted several texts, which are very explicit in the denunciation of future punishments— But the difficulty is to conceive where in the new Testament, any countenance is to be found for the opposite belief— We remembered the birth day, of our Son John this day 27. And I did not forget that of my fathers decease, this day four years— I read two Sermons of Barrow, upon the love of our neighbour— Much more satisfactory than those of the last Sunday— He seems indeed greatly embarrassed with his text; “thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself[”]—for the love of our neighbour; he has no lack of argument— But he worries himself excessively to prove that this Love should equal in degree that which we entertain for ourselves— It is obvious that this text is to be received with some modification— Self-love is a law of physical nature, given by God as the means of self-preservation— The Love of our neighbour is enjoined by Christ as a duty, and in prescribing it he assigned Self-love as the object of comparison, the standard by which it was to be measured— It does not imply that it should be equal in degree to that with which it is compared— When Christ says be ye perfect, even as your father which is in heaven is perfect, he did not intend to require of his disciples a perfection equal to that of God— He pointed them to a model for imitation. And so it is of the Love of our neighbour compared with self Love— If Barrow had duly considered this, he would have saved himself much laborious argument to prove that possible, which is not possible— I walked this evening with Charles to Coll. Quincy’s where we spent an hour.— Mrs Quincy with her daughters Sophia and Anna called to see our Ladies yesterday— Mrs Quincy, Susan and Sophia returned this Evening to Cambridge. Anna, the youngest daughter remains with her brother.
5. V. Monday.

This was the day of the celebration of National Independence. I had been invited to attend at the Railway Church, and at the Anti-masonic celebration at Boston, both of which I declined. It can never again be to me a day of mere festivity— As the birth day of one of my Sons, and as the day of my father’s decease, it combines every interest and feeling that has power over the heart and too much of solemnity for the noisy mirth of a public festival.
I would henceforth pass it in the bosom of my family and in useful occupation— I was employed this day with Charles; continuing to make out the Catalogue of my books. I planted also at the lower end of my Nursery two rows of Cherries and Cherry Stones for Stocks— All from my own mazzard tree, and all stones sinking in water. Mr Crosby of New-York, with his Son paid me a visit— Son of Dr Crosby whom I saw there in 1785. and who was brother to my uncle Peter’s wife— This Same Mr Crosby was the person who owned a large Estate in the Island of Jamaica, which was escheated or cheated away from him— He says he has given up all expectation of ever recovering any part of it— My brother was here this morning and Robert Buchanan who has just finished his course as a Cadet at West Point arrived— Mr Richardson of Hingham the member of Congress called this afternoon; returning from the celebration, at the Railway Meeting house and Hotel. Mr Beale was here in the Evening to remind me of the dinner of the Directors of the Neponset Bridge, to-morrow at Squantum— I began reading this morning the oration against Piso, having yesterday finished that for Coelius. This Coelius was one of the secondary men of the age, whose friendship for Cicero and his intimacy with him has given him his best Passport to the Memory of Ages— The Letters from 8 to 16 of the familiar Epistles Book 2. are Letters from Cicero to him. The whole 8th. Book consists of Letters from Coelius to Cicero. He was a man of loose political and moral principles, and in the civil Wars of Caesar and Pompey, changed sides once or twice— In the third Book of Caesar’s Commentaries on the Civil War, Section 20. is an account of his last Adventures and Death— In this Cause Coelius was accused of having borrowed money of Clodia, and also of having attempted to poison her. This Clodia, was the wife of Metellus Caesar, one of the infamous Sisters of the infamous Clodius— The most remarkable part of the Oration is the manner in which Cicero discredits her testimony and exposes her vices. She appears to have been present at the trial, for the Orator repeatedly addresses her by name. It may be advisable to compare the manner of chastising a female offender with that which the same Speaker uses with men.
6. V. Tuesday.

Charles went this Morning to Boston— I took out my second box for raising trees from seeds and stones which I deposited in the Summer-house cellar Having planted in it nine mazzard Cherry Stones from my tree— I put also into the ground many other stones though from budded or grafted cherries. They almost universally float upon water, and their kernels are usually withered— At noon I bathed with Robert Buchanan and swam from wharf to wharf. Then went to Squantum, and dined upon Chowder with the Directors of the Neponset Bridge— T. Greenleaf, G. W. Beale, Jos. Head and two of his Sons, James H. Foster and his Son William, Mr Wales Edward Miller, My brother and Mr Gourgas, and my Son Charles who had come out from Boston— The buildings which Mr Beale had commenced building last Summer are finished, but there has been no company there as yet this Season— The talk was of a man named John Fuller receiving Teller of the U.S. Branch-Bank Boston; who four days since absconded with 40000 dollars of bills; and with a defalcation of nearly 20000 dollars more— The day before yesterday he delivered himself up, and produced 39500 of the bills he had carried off for the remainder he is still deficient— It appears that there is no practical expedient for protecting the Banks against the frauds of their own subaltern Officers; to so large, and a yet larger amount— After our return home we had a visit from Edmund Quincy with a young man, named Sewall from Montreal, a Grandson as I concluded of Jonathan Sewall— Judge Davis and his brother Isaac P. had been here in the afternoon. Mrs Adams is suffering a severe inflammation of the right eye—for which she this day twice applied a leach; but obtained little relief.
7. V. Wednesday.

Governor Winthrop gave me last Summer a vial of Eyewater, made upon a receipt which he says was brought to this Country by his ancestor, the first Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony— I made little use of it then, but the vial has disappeared during my absence— I wrote this morning to ask another vial of it, for Mrs Adams whose Right eye is very much enflamed— He sent me a vial with an obliging answer, and Charles brought out half a dozen leaches— I planted part of a row of cherries and Stones along by the lowest fence of my Nursery; where they will have the best chance to escape being dug up in my absence; a fate which has befallen hundreds of my trees. I was driven from the Nursery and garden by the heat of the weather— At noon I bathed with Robert Buchanan and my brother’s Son Joseph, and swam from wharf to wharf. Mrs Eustis widow of the deceased Governor, paid Mrs Adams a morning visit— Continued making the Catalogue with Charles after dinner. Finished reading Cicero’s Oration against Piso. The most scurrilously abusive of the whole collection— A continued stream of invective, and of vulgar hard names—delivered in the Senate; not upon any question in deliberation; but merely as the French Translator says, [“]pour savoir sî Pison est un scelerat.” By the Oration de Provinciis Consularibus, Cicero had obtained the recall of Piso from his Province; and upon his return Piso had pronounced an invective against Cicero in the Senate. This was Cicero’s Answer, and its furious personalities have made it a favourite with the modern translators— For Duncan has given it in English, and Wailly in French— But Piso is not now, one of the prime characters of the age, and the reader cannot much sympathize with the feelings of Cicero against him— He was the father of Calpurnia, Caesar’s last wife, was Consul with Gabinius at the time of Cicero’s banishment, and is very severely handled in three or four other Orations besides this— In the Philippics he is mentioned once with commendation, and twice with censure— He was ostensibly against Antony; but betrayed or abandoned the cause of Liberty.
8. V. Thursday.

Mrs. Adams was ill in the Night, and I paid the penalty of imprudence for supping last Night upon Cherries— In the visit to my garden I finished planting the row of cherries and stones by the fence at the bottom of my Nursery. Charles and Robert Buchanan went to Boston, and returned to dine— Mr P. C. Brooks junr paid us a morning visit with judge Porter of Louisiana— My Son John arrived from Washington, which he left last Sunday. My brother was here in the Evening— I was so unwell that this afternoon, I made little progress with Charles in the Catalogue of my books; but part of this day was occupied in reading the papers which belonged to my mother, which Louisa C. Smith lent, or gave me. They are principally the rough copies of Letters which she wrote to many of her friends, and extend from the time of her voyage to England in 1784. down to a few months before her death in 1818— There are several from France—several from England: one or two from Holland—and numbers from her return to this Country in 1788. while she resided at New-York, Philadelphia, and here at Quincy, after my father’s retirement from public life. In the Memoirs of Thomas Brand Hollis, published by John Disney, there are two Letters from my mother to Mr Hollis, one written fromin April 1788 when they were waiting for a wind to sail upon their return to this Country, and the other infrom New-York— The draught of the second of these Letters is among these papers— Several others of the Letters, well worthy of being preserved, are memorials of the family affections and social virtues of the writer. There is one Letter from R. Tyler to her—
9. V. Friday.

Charles and his wife went to Boston, and returned to dine. Robert Buchanan, went with my brother upon a shooting party, without success. We sent for Dr. Holbrook to see Mrs Adams and consulted him for me and for my Son John. Mrs Otis, the widow and her Daughter and Mrs Smith with her daughters Mrs Cruft and Mrs Pickman were here, this afternoon— I continued making out the Catalogue of my library with Charles—and afterwards walked with him to my brother’s; but met him and his wife going to Mr Beale’s. The rest of his family were there.— Elizabeth C. Adams, and Caroline de Wint, my niece Mrs De Wint’s eldest daughter were here this morning— I planted two rows of Cherries and of Cherry stones in the Summer house cellar.
10. V. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine—and this afternoon we finished so much of the Catalogue as contains the books on the permanent shelves in my long Eastern chamber. My Son John and Robert Buchanan went upon a fishing party, with no more success than had the chase of yesterday— I called upon Lewis Bass and upon my tenants Samuel Curtis and Harvey Field, neither of whom was prepared to receive me— I wrote to T. B. Adams junr. concerning my father’s bequest to him— Two persons by the names of King and Tolman, of Randolph called from motives of curiosity, and as they said of good will: and towards Evening judge Story paid me a visit— I read the remainder of the copies of my mother’s Letters, left with me, by Louisa C. Smith— Finished also the Oration for Cneius Plancius— This man had been quaestor in Macedonia at the time of Cicero’s exile; had received and entertained him with the most devoted friendship; when deserted by many others, and denied a refuge in the Island of Sicily; by the Praetor of that Province— Three years after Plancius was a Candidate for the Office of AEdile, and was successful— His disappointed competitor Laterensis, prosecuted him, upon the Licinian Law de Sodalitiis, or bribery by treating— A Law enacted the year before, by which the Prosecutor was authorised to appoint the judges; while in other cases the judges were drawn by lot from lists nominated by each of the parties— In this case Cicero calls upon the prosecutor for specific testimony in support of his charge—denies that he has any to produce; and complains that he has misconstrued mere acts of kindness, and the ardent zeal of Plancius’s friends into corruption. He complains also of the selection of the judges by Laterensis; that he had not chosen them from the tribe, where the principal corruption was charged. He accounts for the success of Plancius in the elections from causes not mortifying to him, for Laterensis himself had been a friend to Cicero; who accordingly treats him with much delicacy and respect— He remarks upon the motives which prevail among the people in giving their votes—and tells very amusingly the story how his own self-complacency and vanity had been mortified, upon his return from Sicily, after his Service there as Quaestor— He relates with much detail the circumstances of his own exile; his exclusion from Sicily and the exceeding kindness of Plancius to him on that occasion— He expatiates on his obligation of gratitude to Plancius, and takes that opportunity to introduce a feeling panegyric upon the virtue of Gratitude itself. He glances also, at the charges of inconsistency, already brought against him, for his recent change of policy, and his compliances to the will of Pompey and Caesar.
11. IV:30. Sunday— My age 63.

My grand climacteric is turned, and I enter upon the sixty-fourth year of my age. In turning back to the notice of the last year’s anniversary, the thought presses upon me of how little has since been effected of that preparation which even then formed an essential part of my duty— The day, and the discourses that I heard should have solemnized my feelings beyond an ordinary pitch— Mr Peter Whitney preached both parts of the day from Job. 14.10. “But man dieth and wasteth away; yea, man giveth up the ghost, and where is he?” With the exception of the question at the end of this verse, the text contains only a saying of trivial morality.— The question, formed the subject of both the discourses— Mr Whitney stated four distinct doctrines, concerning the future state of man— 1. Eternal Punishment to the wicked. 2. annihilation, also confined to the impenitent. 3. A future state of happiness, but not of punishment— 4. Temporary punishment, but final universal Salvation— He gave his own opinions in favour of this last system, which is not that of the sect called universalists. Their doctrine excludes all future punishment. Upon this Subject we know nothing but what is contained in the Scriptures, and as I read them they do denounce judgment, severe judgment, hereafter, for sins committed here— The term of punishment is threatened for ages of ages—indefinite time but not for eternity— There is one passage in which Christ bids his disciples fear him who is able to destroy both body and Soul, in Gehenna—and there is one passage of St. Paul, which seems to promise ultimate universal Salvation—but it is not decisive and the general tenor of the New Testament, gives no encouragement to the hope of any final remission of penalties— But the universalists still believe the Scriptures. I read also the two Sermons of Barrow, upon Charity— The second of them upon the motives, and arguments to Charity—aloud to my wife— And it is much the best of the Sermons of this writer that I have yet read— The arguments are somewhat overcharged; and the motives presented are perhaps too generally selfish— The Style is rough, and the language often obsolete— Many words then in common use have lost not their meaning, but their delicacy. There is a homeliness in the language of all the preachers of that age— Barrow is copious in thought—and his division of the Subject, first into the nature, properties and Acts of Charity, and then into the Motives and Arguments to it is good; but his subdivisions are too numerous, and running into one another cause numerous repetitions. In the discourse upon the motives and arguments to charity there is eloquence and pathos— I passed the Evening at home— No Company— Louisa C. Smith dined with us.
12. IV. Monday.

My wife was again taken severely ill in the Night; the inflammation of her eye returning with extreme pain— Leaches were applied with imperfect success— Charles brought a supply of them from Boston— After breakfast I sent for Dr Holbrook, and in the afternoon for Dr. Woodward, who came, and applied the leaches— The day was rainy, with a cold North-east wind, which confined us to the house. The afternoon I spent with Charles in working upon the Catalogue; completing that of my books in the Library, and taking up those in the adjoining Entry.— I planted a few cherries and stones, in the intervals between my young apple-trees of this years growth. Every one of these that I transplanted lives; but none of them grow. The winter will be their trial— I find the Slug worm upon the leaves of my young plum trees, and the lice, aphides on the tenderest leaves of the two year old Apple trees. We have now an abundance of currants, and rasberries. I wrote to N. Bowditch and Daniel Treadwell, declining to deliver the
introductory Lecture, next October, to the Mechanic Institution— Began reading the Oration for Milo—and have now none left that I had not heretofore read— Of the others I read yesterday the last—for Caius Rabirius Postumus—a short one Gabinius, Cicero’s old Enemy, after his return from Syria, was prosecuted de Majestate and acquitted— Then de pecuniis repetundis and condemned— At the earnest solicitation of Pompey, sustained by Caesar, Cicero defended Gabinius, though on the second Prosecution without success— The charge was that Gabinius had received ten thousand Talents from Ptolemy Auletes, king of Egypt, to restore him to his kingdom, without authority from the Senate, and contrary to the Sibylline verses— The Sentence upon Gabinius condemned him therefore to the payment of a fine of 10000 Talents— His whole fortune being inadequate to this, Rabirius Postumus was prosecuted under the clause of the Law, by which in such cases, the money might be recovered from any person to whom it should come, and Postumus was charged with having received a part of it— The defense is put by Cicero upon two grounds—first that the provision of the Law was not applicable to Postumus, who was a Roman Knight—and secondly that Postumus far from having received the king’s money had ruined himself by lending money to the king— The Prosecutor had reproached Cicero for his reconciliation with Gabinius, and he replies to this charge that he will never be ashamed to make his enmities mortal and his friendships perpetual— He strenuously denies that he had undertaken the defence of Gabinius from fear of the displeasure of Pompey; but his apologetic Letter to Lentulus Spinther holds a different language. The true account is doubtless in the Letter.
13. IV:30. Tuesday.

My wife was somewhat relieved, from the inflammation of the eye, but was still confined to her bed— I had barely an opportunity to visit my plants in the garden, but to do nothing. The rain was afterwards unintermitted the whole day, and I wasted my time— Part of the afternoon occupied on the Catalogue of the Library— Continue the Oration for Milo, Read an Article in the English Quarterly Review upon the French and British Peerage; and two in the 68th number of the North American Review—one upon a recent publication of the Letters of Joseph the second of Austria; and one a reply to the Article in the 99th number of the Edinburgh Review upon American Literature. The Article in the Quarterly is apparently from the pen of Southey or from his school— It is curious, as well for its doctrines, as for a historical Review of the principal aristocratic families of England. It is surprising how few of those families remain— The jealousies of the reigning families against them, and the tragical end of almost every distinguished man among them for a succession of ages, afford matter for profound speculation. The writer shews and complains that from the time of the fall of the Coalition Ministry, and the accession of William Pitt as prime Minister, a new system with regard to the creation of Peers has been adopted— The house of Lords has been about doubled in numbers—consisting in 1768 of 199. peers, and now of 328 besides representative peers and bishops, in all about 400. By this multiplication of peers he argues that the character of the house of Lords and the practical constitution of Great-Britain has been changed— The additional numbers, and the admission of men merely for riches acquired in trade, have sunk the Aristocratic weight and power of the house; and the removal from the lower house of all the men of wealth and family, which were formerly its principal ornament
have also impaired its consideration, and weakened its influence. The general tendency of the Article is to undermine the reputation of William Pitt as a Statesman, and to represent him as influenced by an involuntary and perhaps unconscious prejudice against the Aristocracy— This is doubtless true, and that prejudice was much stronger in George Canning than in Pitt— They both partook of the Spirit of the age, which is irresistibly republican; and anti-hereditary; but nature will ultimately vindicate her rights— The pride of blood is now invidious and odious.— It hides and disguises itself; but it can never be extinguished for it is inseparable from the natural affections between Parent and Child— To suppress it would be to eradicate one of the principal virtues of human nature. The article upon Joseph the Second gives some additional insight into his character, which was that of an ordinary mind, flattered by the delusions of hereditary Supreme power, into a self-conceit of greatness— Frederick the second and Catherine of were distinguished for their Talents—and flattered into prodigies, by the literary trumpeters whom Louis the 14th. had taught them to count— Joseph fancied himself equal to Frederic or Catherine—and as much of Frederics fame was built upon his religious infidelity, Joseph thought he too must be a philosopher and reformer. This was the principal cause of his misfortunes and disappointments. His mind was never steady, and it is half a century since I heard that he was subject to vertiginous wanderings in the dog days— The Letters cited in this review indicate eccentricity. Of the Article upon the tone of British Criticism I may speak hereafter.
14. IV:30. Wednesday.

Charles, with Robert Buchanan went to Boston, and returned to dine. John upon a fishing party. Mrs Adams is slowly convalescent— After dinner I rode with Charles’s wife to Weymouth, and paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Cotton Tufts— We returned after Sunset. Abigail S. Adams was here— Showers. I finished the Oration for Milo: and read also that which is styled for Marcellus—but it is only a personal address to Caesar, thanking him for consenting to the return of Marcus Marcellus from exile— These are considered as among the best of his Orations, and are included both in the French and English Selections of the Translators.— The Oration for Milo is said not to have been delivered, but composed after his condemnation, and sent to him while in Exile at Marseilles. The death of Clodius was one of the most important Events of that period. He was in fact murdered by the order, and the Servants of Milo— Their meeting was accidental— The brawl between their Servants unpremeditated—but Clodius being wounded had taken refuge in a house where Milo caused him to be dragged and despatched— The whole defence of Cicero therefore, rests upon a false statement of facts; and Milo was justly condemned, though he rendered a real Service to the Republic, by putting an end to that mischievous demagogue Clodius. The argument of Cicero, founded upon circumstances and probabilities is very ingenious and convincing: but he assumed his facts, and they were totally different from those proved by the testimony. There is something ridiculous in this cold blooded composition of our eloquent discourse, upon imaginative facts, after a trial and Sentence of condemnation upon the real facts— The Oration for Milo has therefore never been a favourite of mine, especially as the true history of the trial is so discreditable to the Spirit of Cicero. He was disconcerted and intimidated by the military guard of Pompey and the frantic clamours of the Clodian rabble. This was very natural and excusable, and if the Oration is considered
as an expedient to redeem the loss of reputation incurred at the trial, it has been eminently successful— The Address of thanks to Caesar in behalf of Marcellus is of a very different character; and I cannot separate from it the Sentiment of humiliation at the thought that a man like Cicero should have been reduced to the necessity of addressing Caesar, more as a Slave to a Master, than as one Proconsular Roman Senator to another— One of the consequences of this Oration has been to conciliate the minds of men, favourably to the character of Caesar; the most strangely compounded personage that ever appeared in human form. Angel and Daemon shared him between them; and his transcendant virtues apologize for the flattery which Cicero administers to him in this and in two other Orations. Yet they are not those in which the Orator himself appears to the greatest Advantage.
15. IV. Thursday.

My Sons John and Charles and Robert Buchanan made a fishing party to Cohasset, whence they returned sunburnt this Evening. Deacon Spear, called for the subscription for Captain Jenkins— Mr John Welles, his wife and daughter were here this afternoon at tea— I rode with my two daughters to the farms and Neponset Bridge— Edmund Quincy was here in the Evening— I read the Oration for Ligarius, one of the shortest; but which is said to have atchieved one of the greatest triumphs of Eloquence— Ligarius had been in arms against Caesar in the African War; but two of his brothers had been on Caesar’s side— After the War, Ligarius was living in exile— His brothers, cast themselves at Caesar’s feet, and Cicero joined them in supplication to Caesar for his pardon. Caesar was disposed to grant it, but Quintus AElius Tubero, who had himself been in Pompey’s army, and at the battle of Pharsalia, entered a formal complaint that Ligarius had made the African campaign. Caesar then transferred the trial from his own house to the forum— It was to be sure as Cicero says a crimen novum et inauditum. Caesar was sitting as a judge to try a man for having been against him in the civil War, at the prosecution of another who had been on the same side— But Plutarch says he had predetermined to condemn Ligarius, and suffered Cicero, to plead for him, only for the pleasure of hearing an eloquent harangue. As the Orator proceeded however his discourse caused vehement emotions in the mind of his hearer, and repeated changes of colour in his face; till when Cicero came to the passage about the battle of Pharsalia, the Dictator was so much discomposed, that several papers fell from his hands, and he pardoned Ligarius. This is a story which favours of the marvellous, and was perhaps invented, after the death both of Caesar and Cicero— Caesar was merciful in his victory— More so than any other leader of the civil Wars—far more so than Pompey would have been had he succeeded— Caesar seems to have been a man prepared by Providence to break down the Roman Republic and turn it into a Monarchy. But the Oration for Ligarius is not one of those which the friends of Freedom can read with much satisfaction— There is in it too much suppression of the free Spirit of the Speaker; too much servility—too much adulation to Caesar— Its greatest merit, is in the art with which the Orator works upon the Passions of the Master— Upon his pride— Upon his generosity; upon his love of fame—upon his fears— There is a mingled sensation of pain at beholding the greatest and purest mind of Rome, stooping in supplication to an inferior, and of pleasure at observing the ascendancy which it maintains by its influence, subjecting military supremacy itself to the overruling dominion of intellect. This is the glory of the Oration for Ligarius, and of its author.
16. IV:30. Friday.— Bath.

This was one of the hottest days there has been for several years. My Thermometer hanging within the house, near the Southern East window of my chamber was at 87. Dr Holbrook who was here in the afternoon said his was for half an hour at 97. and along the middle of the day at 95. Charles and his wife went into Boston and returned to dine. She was much overcome by the heat, in coming out— I bathed after breakfast with Robert Buchanan and swam from wharf to wharf. The blaze of the Sun soon drove me in from the garden; where the weeds are still Lords of the ascendant— Turnep-seeds sown week before last up, and two old seeds, perhaps melons, which have been 18 months in an open box, and which I cast away last week in two places amid the grass which I hoed up to plant cherry-stones in them. Dr George Parkman with his daughter and R. G. Shaw paid a short visit in the afternoon; and Mr Beale and Mr Miller in the Evening— Towards Sunset I rode with Mary, and R. Buchanan to Braintree— Devoted a couple of hours after dinner with Charles to my Catalogue of Books. Taking now those in the upper bed-chamber. Red the Oration for Dejotarus— Similar in many respects to that for Ligarius— Addressed to Caesar in his own house; to save Dejortarus from the loss of his kingdom, upon a charge made by one of his own Delegates to Rome, that he had intended to poison Caesar, when he was extending to him the hospitality of his house— At the bottom of the accusation was Castor, the grandson of Dejotarus himself; whose object was to obtain the kingdom of Galatia, of which his Grandfather was to be stripped— In this Oration the eloquence of Cicero is said to have failed— Dejotarus lost his kingdom, but perhaps recovered it after the death of Caesar which happened a few months after the delivery of this Oration— An argument before a usurping Dictator, to dissuade him from dethroning a barbarian king, gives no occasion for sympathy or sublimity— There is nothing in it to engage the affections, and Cicero himself did not pride himself upon this work— It has however found favor both with the French and English Translators.
17. IV:30. Saturday.

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— This was the second of a succession of days of extreme Summer heat— I barely looked into the Garden but soon took refuge in the house; from the intense power of the Sun— Bathed with my son John and Robert Buchanan. Swam from wharf to wharf, wearing a white night cap which gives full protection to the head, from the heat of the Sun. My Son Charles’s wife was confined to her chamber with a Sick head ache the whole day— About Sun-set I rode with my son John and his wife over Milton Hill, and was employed with Charles after dinner upon the Catalogue— The heat disqualifies me for writing— I this day first saw two shoots from the stems of the willow which about the tenth of June I cut off near the ground— Charles stuck it into the ground near the bottom of the Nursery. There are several shoots from the root which I left in the ground; one of which I this day found was 13 inches long— Those from the top-stem shew the time which it takes the severed twig, to get a new root— The transplanted young apples trees have taken about the same time to put forth new leaves— The young Oaks and Horse-Chesnuts have all ceased growing for the present year. The plums and two yearling apples are arrested or checked by small black-flies, Aphides and ants which lodge themselves in the germinating leaves and curl them up— Some of the peach twigs are mouldy.
I read the first Philippic of Cicero. This Series of fourteen Orations, is principally remarkable, as containing the last accents of the expiring Liberty of Rome— They were composed, and, with the exception of the second, delivered in the years of Rome 709 and 710 the 63 and last year of Cicero’s Life— They follow immediately after the three Orations addressed to Caesar, and in character are strongly contrasted with them— By his victories in the civil Wars, Caesar had made himself the master of the world— Orations addressed to him were supplications for life and pardon— After his death the struggle of Cicero was to restore the Republic, and Antony occasionally affected to have the same object— The first Philippic is eminently beautiful— And is historically important as presenting a full exposition of Cicero’s motives, for attempting to pass into Greece, there to await the ensuing year and a change of Consuls; and for afterwards changing that intention, returning to Rome, and taking his Seat in the Senate— His answer to the threats of Antony for his absence from the Senate the preceding day, is full of moderation and of dignity. His address to the other Consul, Dolabella, who had been his Son in Law, and disciple is affectionate, and deeply affecting; and there is a thrilling solemnity, in the repeated intimations which he gives, that he sees and despises the imminent danger to his own life, with which he is surrounded.
18. IV:30. Sunday

Third day of extreme Summer heat— Dr Holbrook was here, and bled my Son John’s wife, to whose confinement we look forward with an interest, mingled with hopes and fears which words cannot express— We heard Mr Capen; a person settled at South Boston—his morning text from Luke 16.5.— “How much owest thou unto my Lord.” And that of the afternoon from John 1.29. “Behold the lamb of God, which taketh away the sin of the world.”— Mr Capen is a Unitarian, and explained what he understood by this afternoon’s text. I could not write; but began this morning upon the second Philippic, and read two Sermons of Barrow, upon a Peaceable Temper and Carriage— In these discourses I perceive that which of late years has brought up Barrow again as a favourite of the Tory critics in England. In presenting his arguments for cultivating a peaceable temper, he forbids all political disquisitions and enquiries. Passive obedience and non-resistance figure in his reasoning as unequivocally as in the song of the Vicar of Bray— He assumes that the people in general have neither knowledge nor capacity to judge of the operations of the Government— That it is their duty not to meddle with them at all, not even to resist or to complain of misgovernment— But if Providence gives them bad Rulers to submit in Silence, and await the retributive Justice of Providence. This is neither palatable nor rational doctrine; nor would it be tolerated in England at this day, from the sturdiest candidate for a Mitre— Barrow was a Mathematician, and his Sermons, have something of the appearce of demonstration of problems. He seldom touches the heart— He has some observations upon human life and manners, but they are seldom profound, and still more rarely original— He generally quotes from the new Testament in its original Greek words— He quotes much also from the fathers, also in their Greek Original— The french divines also frequently cite the fathers, but they are the barrenest of all human authorities— I do not recollect a single sentence quoted from an ancient father, which struck me as deserving to be remembered— This Evening my daughters rode out with Robert Buchanan, and I went in a Chaise with
my Son John to Braintree, stopped at Solomon Thayer’s, and saw his new grain; a patch of which he reaped yesterday— He has now been told that it is the Leghorn wheat; and that the straw is that of which the Leghorn hats are made— He has now ascertained that it is a fall grain and must be sown in September— He has now an acre of it growing; like mine sown this Spring; and which will therefore not ripen till next Summer. This small patch was an experiment which he made with a small parcel of his seed on a vacant spot of ground and it has now come to maturity— Edward Cranch and MrsDawes called upon us this Evening.
19. IV:30. Monday—

The night was so intensely warm that I had scarcely any Sleep, and was accordingly so feeble and languid this day, that I was unable to continue the Catalogue with Charles— I found this day another squash or melon seed received last year from Edward Wyer has come up in the transverse row of the Summer-house cellar— A part of the walnuts on my hickory tree, are thriving well; but there are not many on the tree; and of the few, a part are stunted in their growth, and are already dropping from the tree— With my Son John and Robert Buchanan I bathed at the Mount Wollaston Beach, where I found the old Lime trees in blossom. I have totally failed in the attempt to raise any of these from the Seed, but must yet not despair— In the Evening I rode to Braintree with my two daughters— Continued reading the second Philippic, in the effort of which I am drawn away by a multiplicity of translations, notes and Commentaries. The preface of d’Olivet to the Latin Edition of the Orations is a Philippic against the Commentators— Du Ryer’s translation, is rather a paraphrase; yet it reads more naturally than that of Wailly— Duncan’s renders most faithfully the thoughts of the Original, but there is a want of the Elegance which constitutes the greatest charm of Cicero’s Style— In the judicial Orations, Duncan translates the Addresses to the Judges. Judices, by the words My Lords which sound very aukwardly— I have read also the Articles in the quarterly Reviews upon insanity, and the Mexican Pearl fishery, and that in the North-American upon the first Volume of Moore’s Life of Byron— The last is mere inanity. The Pearl-fishery of Calefornia is a hoax; but the account in the quarterly of the manner in which persons in England may be and sometimes are consigned to private mad-houses is surprising— I received a Letter from my niece Mrs Susan B. Clarke.
20. IV:45. Tuesday.

There was a fresher breeze than the preceding days, but the heat of the Sun was still too scorching to admit of industrious occupation in the house, or of much perambulation in the Garden— The Sun has killed two of my young Apple trees at the bottom of the Garden Nursery— Note an Apple tree at the entrance of the Nursery— Now first in full bearing—Remember to gather seeds of the esculent vegetables in the Garden, at the proper times— Bath with John and Robert Buchanan— Swam from wharf to wharf. Rode with Mary towards Evening; and gathered a quantity of Elder flowers; a fort night too late. My brothers two daughters, and Mary Foster were here in the Evening— I received a Letter from William H. Crawford, concerning certain incidents at Cabinet Meetings. 15. 16. 17. 18. July 1818— A Letter also from Cesar Moreau, informed me of my election as honorary Member of the French Society of Universal Statistics. Finished reading the second Philippic of Cicero; called by Juvenal the divine— Antony had composed an Oration in answer to the first philippic, full of violence and fury— He had pronounced it in the Senate; but Cicero had not been present to hear him— His friends had dissuaded him from attending the Meeting,
under apprehensions that Antony would resort to personal violence to destroy him— But Antony must have published his Oration; for the second Philippic is a professed and formal reply to it— Cicero wrote it at one of his Country Seats, and published, but never delivered it. Throughout the whole of this fierce contention, Cicero and Antony never met face to face— The Oration nevertheless supposes the presence of Antony— The greater part of it is addressed directly to him, and twice at least, in the 13th. and 34th. Sections it speaks of Antony as if manifesting signs of perturbation, while the Speaker is probing him to the quick— Much of the personal invective in this Oration is low and vulgar; but the exordium is inimitably beautiful, and the peroration is sublime—and if considered as it should be in connection with the subsequent Events, the foul proscription and the brutal murder of the Orator it is inexpressibly pathetic— The exhortation to Antony, to restore at last the Liberty of his Country, is so admirable in itself, that the reader scarcely thinks to enquire why it should be wasted upon such a man as the discourse has proved Antony to be— The character of Caesar as contrasted with that of Antony, is drawn with wonderful vigour and accuracy. The first 17. Sections are only replies to charges against Cicero by Antony. The Attack upon him by the review of his whole life begins at the 18th. The peroration at Chapter 44—
21. IV.30. Wednesday.

This is to be noted hereafter as an extraordinary hot Summer, in this region— We have now the seventh day in Succession; of a burning and almost constantly cloudless Sun— My Thermometer ranges between 80 and 90. Night and day— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Mr G. W. Beale came and invited us to a Chowder party at Squantum to-morrow— Eliakim Turner was here this Evening; a messenger from Saml. Curtis; and paid me his rent to the 1st. of April— He not renting the house the present year. Bathed with my Son John and Robert Buchanan immediately after noon—and rode to Braintree with my two daughters before and after Sunset; making a further collection of Elder flowers on the way— At the foot of Penn’s Hill on the Braintree side. On our return home we stopped at Mr John Greenleaf’s, where Mrs Edward Miller, and Mrs Nicholson were visiting. Mr Greenleaf’s eldest daughter with four small children two girls and two boys were there— Fahrenheit’s Thermometer was at 87. at 10 this Evening in my chamber— Upon my morning visit to the Garden, I buried a heap of steeped currents in the Nursery, behind the gate at the entrance; between a row of cherry-stones, and the fence—opposite an Apple-tree, now first bearing full, and which is perhaps a grafted golden pippin— The shoot from the amputated willow-stock in the Summer house cellar, is this day 17 inches long, having grown 4 inches in the four days since I measured it before. The shoots from the severed stem, in the nursery look doubtfully— I read the third Philippic, on the 19th. of September Antony had delivered in the Senate his answer to the first Philippic—at the distribution of Provinces by the Senate immediately after the death of Caesar Macedonia had been assigned to Antony, and citerior Gaul confirmed to Decimus Brutus, Caesar himself having before his death designated him to it. But Macedonia was not well situated for the present designs of Antony; and he had obtained by an appeal from the Senate to the People, the designation to the Government of citerior Gaul, with a view by the means of his armed force, to have the City always under his controul— About the last of September he left Rome, and went to Brundisium, where four Legions joined him from Macedonia— But two of those Legions deserted him, and joined the standard of Octavius who was upon his own authority collecting an army against him— Antony then summoned an assembly of the Senate to declare Octavius an Enemy to the Republic; but upon the defection of the two Legions, changed
changed his plan, and proceeded with three Legions to his command in citerior Gaul, and to besiege Decimus Brutus in Mutina— On the 10th. of December the Tribunes of the People for the ensuing year entered upon their Office, and convoked an assembly of the Senate, to consider of a guard of safety for the designated Consuls, on the first of January, when they were to come into Office— The third philippic is as delivered at this Meeting of 19. Decr. and it closes with a form of a decree which was adopted by the Senate charging the new Consuls to provide a guard of safety for holding a Meeting of the Senate on the first of January, and in the mean time approving the acts of the Provinces of Gaul, of Decimus Brutus, and of Octavius Caesar against Antony, and of the conduct of the two legions which had deserted him—the rewards of all which should be presented by the Consuls for the deliberation of the Senate on the first of January— Cicero now considers Antony as waging war “against the Republic”; and urges in general terms the most vigorous measures against him—
22. IV:30. Thursday— Fahrenheit 90.

I visit my Garden, every morning after breakfast, and would if possible every day make some new observation upon the progress of vegetation— But in this as in many other things I perceive the decays of Memory; and I forget even the names of the plants which I learnt from Ouseley— With my Sons John and Charles, I went to the Chowder party at Squantum; where we met my brother, his two daughters, and his son Joseph H. Mrs Antony Baxter her two daughters and Son, Mr G. W. Beale and his eldest daughter, Mary Foster, Mr Gourgas, Mr Greene, Thomas and Mrs Greenleaf, and their two daughters Daniel and Mrs Greenleaf, Mary Harrod, Edward and Mrs Miller and their daughter, Mr and Mrs Nicholson, and their daughter, Miss Otis—President and Mrs Quincy, and their daughters Abigail and Anna Coll Josiah and Mrs Quincy, Mrs Ripley, Louisa C. Smith; Mr and Mrs P Whitney; their two daughters and two Sons and Dr Woodward—and Robert Buchanan. Several of us bathed under the Squantum Rock; and part of the company went out for half an hour in a two mast sailing boat; returning sooner than was intended, in fear of a squall which passed off to the westward— The Chowder was much of the common cast and passed for good. Of the pastime at Bowls I did not partake— President Quincy with Mr Greene, left the company early to return to Cambridge— We came home soon after, and I rode to Braintree with my Son John and my two daughters— The Evening was oppressively warm, and the night came with a flat calm— In the morning I had read the fourth and ten Sections of the fifth Philippic— The fourth is a very short address to the People, merely announcing to them the substance of the decree adopted by the Senate, on the 19th. of December, at the motion of Cicero. He represents the assembly of the people to be numerous beyond all former example; and he notices a universal show of applause from them, when he informed them that the Senate had in substance declared Antony a Public Enemy— But they had not declared him so in form. The fifth Philippic was delivered to the Senate, on the first day of January 710. when the New Consuls Hirtius and Pansa entered upon their Office— Fufius Calenus had proposed that a deputation of Senators should be sent to Antony, to require of him submission to the Laws— This measure
was strenuously opposed by Cicero, and no decision was made on that day— But three days after the Senate determined to send the deputation— The Senators were in part intimidated and in part disaffected— The result of this day’s deliberation was portentous of the final event— The cause of the Republic was lost—
23. IV:15. Friday.

The weather of the Night has been for some time almost suffocating, and I resorted last Night to a Mattress on the floor of my Library. This day the wind was Northeasterly, and Fahrenheit down to 74. Charles and his wife left us, to spend a week or fortnight with Mr Brooks at Medford. In the garden, the vegetation of my young trees presenting no new point of observation every day, I attempt to turn my attention, to its usual and useful vegetables— There are in one bed plants of Hyssop, now in blossom, Mint, Rue, Sage, Tansy soon to blossom— Parsley adjoining— Then a small bed of Strawberries set out last Spring. Augustus Farrar was at last poling some of the beans— I planted 1. Cherry and 1. Stone in 5 of the row of ten stands upon which I propose to raise fruit from the seed or Stone— Bathed with Robert Buchanan, soon after noon, and swam from wharf to wharf.— Towards Sunset, rode with my Son John and his wife over Milton hill— Then walked with Robert to my brother’s where we found Mr T. Greenleaf and his family, Mr Beale—Edward Cranch, and his Sister Mrs Dawes—and Mrs Nicholson, who with Abigail S Adams sung and played on the Piano— I slept away the after dinner time on my Mattress. Read the remnant of the fifth and the sixth Philippic— The fifth or first of January Oration, was upon the honours to be decreed to the Brutus’s, to Lepidus, and to Octavius Caesar, for resisting Antony, and to the Martian and fourth Legions for deserting him— This is the Oration in which Cicero pledges himself, with so much solemnity to the virtue and patriotism of Octavius Caesar, in which he was so fatally disappointed— The pledge was indeed compulsive— The creatures of Antony, supported their motions, for treating with him, by their distrust of the sincerity and good faith of Octavius; and Cicero who had no hope, but in the extermination of Antony, was forced to accept as genuine the professions of Octavius, who was indispensable for carrying on the War against him— Still on the 3d. of January the Senate determined to send a deputation of 3 of its Members to Antony—and Cicero at the request of the Tribune Apuleius, addressed the People, to inform them of what had been done by the Senate— He says he understands that the People disapprove the deputation to Antony, as he did;—but he adds that the deputation amounts to a declaration of War, if Antony should not submit to the authority of the Senate, which it was a perfect certainty that he would not— Cicero therefore advises the people to wait with patience till the return of the delegates, which would demonstrate beyond all controversy the necessity of pushing on vigorously the War— He closes the 6th. Philippic by assuring the Quirites, that other people can endure Servitude, but that Liberty was the peculiar property of the Romans— He mistook his tense.
24. IV. Saturday.

The day and Evening were again excessively sultry, and I was proportionably idle— I planted a row of promiscuous steeped cherries, and of whole ripe currents red and white along by the fence between my Nursery and
the garden. I have never yet been able to raise currents, strawberries, or any of the small seeded fruits from the seed—but I now repeat my experiments— Bathed alone, and swam from wharf to wharf— This afternoon a Roman Catholic Priest by the name of Woodley called upon me and solicited a subscription for building a Church at Pawtucket Rhode-Island— He said he had come here at the request of some Irish Catholics working at the Rail-road; to perform the service of the Church for them at 1/2 past ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning— I said I had several Catholics in my family; some of whom would probably attend. He said the service was to be performed at the house of a Mr Pendergast, which I found was just beyond Arnold’s brook— Mr Woodley said he had been introduced to me at Washington by Mr. Matthews in company with Bishop England— In the Evening I rode with Mary and Robert Buchanan to Milton-hill— We gathered Elder flowers— Mrs Adams in her illness has used leaches, of which there are numbers in the Pond behind our house. But those procured from Europe, are more effective for drawing blood— Most of them die after being once or twice used; but there is an art of keeping them alive for years— We have been these two days observing one in a glass in pond water— A female, which has five young ones in a membranous sac upon the belly, from which they occasionally issue; and to which they return Like every other work of nature; its examination is a perpetual source of wonder— I read the 7th. and six Sections of the 8th. Philippic. The 7th. was delivered in the Senate, before the return of the deputation which had been sent to Antony and of which he again declares his disapprobation. The subjects put in deliberation by the Consul, and by a tribune of the People— Cicero after referring to them, immediately diverges to the War with Antony, and argues against those who were constantly urging for Peace— He undertakes to prove that Peace with Antony, would be disgraceful, dangerous and impracticable— After discussing briefly those three points, he concludes by saying that as to the questions in deliberation he assents to the opinion of Publius Servilius. The first of the deputies to Antony, Servius Sulpicius died just before they reached his camp— The two others Lucius Piso and Philippus returned with insolent answers of defiance from Antony— The Senate therefore passed a severe decree against him; but hesitated whether to call it a War, or a tumult— And his partizans, still clamoured for Peace, and spoke of sending another deputation to Antony. This is ardently opposed by Cicero who in mild language severely censures Calenus for favouring Antony, and the two returned deputies, for receiving and reporting the answer of Antony— There is a passage in the 5th. Section in almost the identical words of Christ— In the body says Cicero, we suffer to be cut off or cauterized any member that injures the rest of the body— That one member, may perish rather than the whole body— So in the body of the Republic, to save the whole, the pestiferous part must be amputated.
25. IV:15. Sunday.

Remarkable change of weather— Morning oppressively warm. Fahrenheit at 87. about noon the wind came suddenly to the Northeast— Heavy Showers and a cold evening followed— Heard Mr Brooks of Hingham; this morning from 2. Corinthians 11–23—“in labours more abundant”—and in the afternoon from Isaiah 13.19 “And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldees excellency, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.” The morning discourse was a panegyric upon the character and writings of Dr Paley, with an enumeration of his works— Mr Brooks commended and recommended them, with rather more enthusiastic admiration than they deserve. The afternoon Sermon was upon the destruction of Babylon, as prophesied by Isaiah two hundred years and by Jeremiah seventy years before it happened— He gave from Herodotus an account of the City, at its highest prosperity and of the manner in which it was taken, by Cyrus, by
draining the bed of the River Euphrates. This subject can never fail in the hands of a moralist upon the vanity of human greatness— Mr Brooks considered the event merely with reference to the prophesies, and did not even allude to the feast of Belshazzar, or to the hand-writing on the wall— He dined with us, and told me that he went out of the usual track in writing Sermons; because he had preached to his hearers to be good, and to do good till not he but they were tired— Mr Quincy the President of the University was here this afternoon, and borrowed of me Tom Morton’s New-England Canaan— Mr Quincy is to deliver an Oration on the 17th. of September upon the completion of the second century Since the settlement of Boston— He spoke to me concerning the grant of a degree to my Son John, and the members of his Class, who were dismissed just before the Commencement at which they were to be graduated— He thinks the degree may be conferred, if the young men who were excluded will ask for it— I found a large striped snake in my nursery this morning—he perceived me and slunk into the wall— I read the remainder of the eighth the ninth and three Sections of the tenth Philippic.— The ninth was upon a question submitted by the Consul Pansa, to the Senate, what honours should be shewn to the Memory of Servius Sulpicius, the deputy who had died while employed on the deputation to Antony— Servilius whose opinion had preceded that of Cicero had proposed the erection at public expence of a sepulchral monument; which Cicero approves, but proposes the addition of a Pedestrian Statue, in support of which motion he pronounces a high and affectionate Panegyric upon Sulpicius, and observes that the life of the dead consists in the Memory of the Living— I began Barrow’s Sermon upon the duty and reward of bounty to the Poor—
26. IV:15. Monday.

A cold Northeast wind, with frequent showers has succeeded the excessive Summer heats of the last ten days and confined me almost entirely to the house. The Althaea trees before my windows, opened their first flowers of the Season this day. I planted a whole cherry, and a stone in each of the three remaining stands, where I propose to raise fruit trees from the seed. I leave the two stands where the squashes have come up— The seed of this plant comes up in a week and opens into two oval seed leaves which spread to be near two inches long and an inch and a third wide; between these comes out in another week a heart shaped leaf on one side, and a denticulated spade shaped leaf on the other—at right angles to the seed leaves. The upper surface of the second pair of squash leaves has whitish spots all over it— This is now the condition of the plants from the two Squash seeds which I sowed the 6th. of this month without expectation that they would come up— That in the Summer house cellar sown three days later is not so far advanced— My attention fixes itself easily upon plants which I put into the ground myself and upon no others— I also planted a row of crushed currents between my two cherry rows, near the raspberry vine at the lower part of my nursery. Read the remainder of the 10th. and ten Sections of the 11th Philippic— The tenth was a debate upon Letters received from Marcus Brutus, and the object of Cicero was to obtain from the Senate their approbation of the military operations of Brutus, in Macedonia, Illyria, and Greece, and to give him a regular command as Proconsul in those Provinces. In the formal motion of Cicero, Brutus is called Quintus Caepio Brutus,
which was explained in the Clavis of Ernesti, that Brutus had taken that name on being adopted by Quintus Caepio his mother’s brother— It appears by this Oration that there was a strong prejudice against Brutus, and that the Senators were much influenced by the fear of giving offence to the veterans of Julius Caesar’s armies— I read also to my wife a Chapter of Butler’s Analogy, and examined Marshall and Abercrombie on gardening, and the management of Fruit-trees— Anniversary of my Marriage.
27. IV. Tuesday.

My Son John and Lieutt. Buchanan went into Boston, and returned after dinner. The day cold, with threats of Showers— Gathered in the garden a Quart of Currants, part of which I steeped in two bottles of New-England Rum, and reserved the rest, for the experiment of planting to ascertain if I can raise them from the seed.— Wrote a short note in answer to Charles, and sent him a short Power to sign for me a Petition for a Meeting of the Stockholders of the State Bank. No copies— Read to my wife part of a Chapter of Butler’s Analogy— Read also the remainder of the 11th. and the 12th. Philippic.— The 11th. was delivered in the Senate, on the account being received, of the treacherous murder of Trebonius, at Smyrna by Dolabella— Trebonius was one of the Assassins of Caesar; and the pretext of Dolabella was to avenge that act— The Senate declared Dolabella, a public Enemy: even the partizans of Antony were among the most violent against him, and Cicero particularly thanks Calenus for the severity of his opinion upon this deliberation— But there was a question to whom the command of the War against Dolabella should be assigned— Cicero most earnestly recommends Cassius; but was opposed by the Consul Pansa. The province of Asia was therefore assigned to the Consuls; but both of them having soon after perished the command did finally devolve upon Cassius, by whom Dolabella was at last vanquished, and put to death. Dolabella had been the friend and Son in Law of Cicero, who alludes to and deplores the fact in this Oration. The 12th Philippic is a sharp remonstrance against a decree adopted by the Senate upon a proposal of the same Consul Pansa, to send a second deputation to Antony: consisting of P. Servilius, and of Cicero himself— It appears he had been prevailed upon to assent for a moment to this measure, upon some equivocal assurances from Antony’s partizans; by which he avows plainly that he had been deceived. He urges with irresistible force the absurdity of a new deputation; the impossibility that it should be successful; and the peculiar incongruity that he should be one of the deputies— Yet he finally concludes that if it should be desired, he would still go, if he could with a prospect of personal safety in performing the Service— I walked this Evening to my brother’s, but saw only his wife and part of his family. Isaac Parker Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of this Commonwealth was struck with palsy on Sunday Morning, and died the same Night. The Court commenced its Session last week at Salem, for the trial of the Murderers of Joseph White— The Chief Justice had delivered an elaborate charge to the Grand Jury. On Saturday they had returned bills of Indictment against three persons, for being concerned in the murder, and the trial was to commence this day. On Saturday Night the Chief Justice came to Boston to spend the Sunday at home; whence he was destined to go, not again to Salem, but to the house appointed for all the living. Isaac Parker, preceded me one year at Cambridge; and perhaps in life— He was a man of good talents, good morals, and good temper— Always popular, and elevated by the favour of his fellow citizens, above the station to which his abilities might have raised him— His life has been eminently fortunate, and though cut short by a sudden stroke, has not lost its character in its close.
28. IV. Wednesday.

Fahrenheit at 65— Showery Night and cloudy day. I had a large square box, one of those which held my books taken into the garden, for the experiments I propose to continue for raising plants from the seeds— I planted in one corner of it a heap of whole and crushed Currents intending to leave them there till next Spring; and I planted a row of them, alongside of the row of young Apple-trees growing from the seed which I planted last Summer: four of which are now six inches high— Of the shoots from the willow stump there are two each 19 inches long; having grown about half an inch a day since they came out— The Horse-Chestnut, American Elm, and Willow have a very rapid growth— The Oak comes next— The Shellbark is slow, and exceedingly difficult to preserve through the winter— Abigail S. Adams spent the day here— Rode with her and Mary, and Lieutt. Buchanan to Braintree, after a visit to Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf. On our return home we left Abby at her father’s. I read the 13th. Philippic, delivered on the occasion of Letters received from Lepidus, urging Peace with Antony. Lepidus was still trimming between the Parties; for he had but a short time before obtained the restitution of Sextus the Son of Pompey the Great. In this Oration Cicero treats the character of Lepidus with great respect, but proves the utter impossibility of Peace with Antony. To complete the demonstration he reads an entire Letter from Antony to Hirtius and Octavius Caesar, and comments upon it sentence by sentence with keen severity. The Letter itself must have been deeply impressive upon those to whom it was written; professing that all of his object was to punish the murderers of Julius Caesar, and that the Senate and their forces were nothing more than relics of the vanquished party of Pompey— The Letter is not disrespectful to Hirtius and Octavius, but insolent, ferociously sarcastic upon the Pompeian party, and inexpressibly bitter upon Cicero— Hirtius and Octavius sent the Letter to Cicero himself, and the use he made of it, decided the Resolution of the Senate against the recommendation of Lepidus. He concludes by assenting to the proposition of Servilius with regard to that recommendation, and by moving in addition a decree of honour in favour of Sextus Pompeius, who had offered his Services against Antony, and who would have marched his force to the deliverance of Decimus Brutus in Mutina, but for the apprehension of giving umbrage to the veterans of Julius Caesar in the armies of Hirtius and Octavius. The fate of the Republic depended upon these Veterans, and it was ultimately decided by them— Neither of the Consuls, Hirtius or Pansa, was cordial to the cause in which they were engaged, and in which they lost their Lives. Lepidus never fully joined in it, and soon united himself with Antony— Octavius basely betrayed it— In several of the Philippics, the fear and jealousy of the Veterans, breaks out in the language of Cicero; and he is always under evident embarrassment in speaking of them.
29. IV. Thursday.

A cold Northeast Storm, confined us to the house, and allowed me only a few minutes for my visit to the garden; where a squirrel perched on the fence near my Shellbark tree gave notice of his purpose to establish his domicil upon it; to await the maturity of the nuts. Our peas in the garden are past—but we have string beans, green corn, Potatoes, Cabbages, Cucumbers, Carrots, Beets and Parsnips— Turneps and Radishes not successful— Summer Squash just ripening. Rhubarb full grown— Rasberries all consumed— Blackberries and whortleberries, come in from abroad. I have had the ground broken up along the Western Wall of my Nursery; and propose to have a hedge fence of bushes to border it— I read the 14th. and last of the Philippics, delivered in the Senate, on the receipt of the intelligence of the battle at Modena, where Antony had been defeated, by the two Consuls, and by Octavius Caesar. From the Oration it appears that the Consul Pansa
had received two dangerous wounds, but Hirtius had then escaped uninjured—this action however was not decisive; and Decimus Brutus was still besieged— Another battle was fought a day or two after, in which Antony was totally defeated, and compelled to raise the Siege, but the Consul Hirtius was killed— Pansa had already died of his wounds. The last Philippic was pronounced in the interval between the two battles, when Cicero supposed both the Consuls to be living. Its object is to propose honours and rewards to the two Consuls and to Octavius and to their troops— He moves that the title of Imperator should be conferred upon the three Commanders, and fifty days of Supplications— That promises of large gratuities and of lands should be renewed to the victorious Soldiers; and that they should be extended to the Parents, Children or brothers of those who had been slain. A funeral eulogy upon them is included in the Oration; which is the last of fifty-six models of Eloquence, left by the greatest Orator that ever lived, and which have survived though not entire the wreck of nineteen Centuries— The Philippics are unmutilated, and are as valuable in the light of historical documents, as in that of consummate monuments of the genius and patriotism of their author. I answered also this day the extraordinary Letter lately received from W. H. Crawford.
30. IV. Friday.

The Northeast Storm continued, and confined us all to the house as in Midwinter— I crushed a few currants, thimbleberries, and whortleberries to keep them till October, and others till next April—and to plant them fall and Spring, for the experiment of raising from the Seed— One of the English Oaks in the midst of Thayer’s Leghorn Wheat is now putting out new leaves— My Nursery red Oak was staked to straiten him— The Leghorn wheat weeded— Many Althaea’s are coming up from seed, self-sown under the trees— The grass chokes them— I cleared it away round one of them to give it a chance to grow— These seeds come out just when the Trees blossom. Is it a general Law?— The black hen, of the Norman breed has been setting upon 19 eggs and this day hatched seven chickens— This is the best breed of domestic fowls in the world; but my efforts to introduce them here have as yet been disappointed— Mr Curtis sent me yesterday a deed from the Executors of W. N. Boylston to Gideon Snow, of Lands in Granville, executed and acknowledged by him and Mrs Boylston, for my signature— I signed it this Evening, and went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s; who took the acknowledgment of it. I answered a Letter from my niece Mrs Susan B. Clark— I read the fragments of Cicero’s Orations— These fragments consist of quotations by various antient authors from twenty Orations, which were extant for several centuries after the death of Cicero, but which have since been lost; and from the missing parts of four which have come down incomplete— They are for the most part very short Single sentences, not easily understood without the context to which they belong; or the comment of the writer by whom they are quoted. Three fourths of them are from Asconius Pedianus, almost cotemporary with Cicero himself; and who even in the age of Augustus wrote a voluminous commentary upon his Orations. It is fortunate for mankind that the Admiration of Cicero’s genius and writings continued from his own age, and was not less enthusiastic under the tyranny of the Caesar’s than it had been while the Republic existed. Virgil and Horace indeed chose to forget him, and in Virgil’s Orabunt Causas Melius, was the sneaking adulation of a Slave— But Cornelius Nepos—Livy—Velleius Paterculus, Juvenal, Quinctilian
were not afraid to express the feelings of honest hearts; and the Power of Eloquence and Patriotism over the mind, never lost its charm— I have now been three Months in going through his Orations; and find ample motive for devoting three more to them, if I should ever have them to spare— The pleadings in private Causes are, fewer than I had supposed— Almost all are political— Almost all connected with the Events of the Orator’s Life.
31. IV:20. Saturday.

Mrs Quincy junr. with her mother, and a daughter of Mr Minot paid a morning visit to the Ladies, and Mrs Quincy returned me the Volume containing Tom Morton’s pamphlet which President Quincy had borrowed last Sunday. John and Lieutt. Buchanan dined at my brother’s— Mary with the child went there to Tea, and I walked there towards Evening— William Foster was there, and returned with his Sister Mary to Boston— The day was clear, but the wind was still at North-east, and the atmosphere chill, and extremely damp. Immediately after Sunset, a thick exhalation rose from the low meadow before my brother’s house— Edward Miller who was there said it infallibly portended a South wind tomorrow— I planted this Morning a row of crushed whortleberries, at the lower part of my nursery, near the thimble-berry vine: and this Evening I gathered from the Lime-tree on the School house lot given by my father to the Town—some of its seeds, which appear to be ripe. But to vary the experiment, and chances of success, I shall gather some of the seeds, every week for the next two months. I began to read Cicero’s Oration for Quintius, which together with that for Roscius of Ameria, I had passed by when on the 28th. of April, I commenced with the Orations; because I had repeatedly, and quite recently read them before— But wishing now to make complete work with Cicero, I intend to read these again; but to proceed with the philosophical works at the same time— I read also to my wife part of two Chapters of Butler’s Analogy.

Day. I rise between four and five, and begin to need the morning lamp. Read three chapters of the New Testament, and two or three pages, of the fragments illustrating the Scriptures, published as Supplements to the English Translation of Calmet’s Dictionary— I had hoped to derive some instruction and entertainment from these; but most of them, are upon subjects not of primary interest. The description of a Caravan, compared with the marshaling of the children of Israel, at the Exodus from Egypt, is curious, and the dissertation upon the Locust is amusing. From the Bible and its Commentaries I pass to Cicero; and read from ten to fifteen Sections of his Orations before Breakfast; occasionally consulting Dictionaries, Comments, Translations, the Life of Cicero, and Crevier’s Roman History. When Charles is here we breakfast at seven—when he is absent, at eight. After breakfast, I spend from one to two hours in my garden—in barren observations upon vegetation. Then from ten to two, am writing and reading miscellaneously in my library. From two to three at dinner— Then in the warm weather sleep till five, the time for tea— After which I ride with Mary in one of the Carriages till dark— Then comes the Bell at 9 O’Clock Supper—and between 10 and 11. the bed— An hour for the swimming bath, when the weather is fine must follow morning or afternoon the course of tide—and sometimes an hour or two for an evening walk and visit. Many afternoons have been absorbed by taking the catalogue of my Library not yet finished— Several lost, by the disqualifying heat of the weather— But the worst symptom is a growing and unresisted repugnance to labour.
